perturbation.original_text: HPS shall pay such amount to SHPS within fifteen days following the end of the applicable month.
perturbation.changed_text: HPS shall pay such amount to SHPS within forty-five days following the end of the applicable month.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying the payment deadline from fifteen days to forty-five days could violate prompt payment laws in some jurisdictions if the actual costs for services were significantly higher. Some states may have regulations requiring healthcare providers to pay their contractors within a shorter timeframe.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of state-specific prompt payment laws for healthcare services.

perturbation.original_text: Unless either party gives the other at least ninety days' prior written notice that it has elected not to extend the term of this Agreement beyond December 31, 1998, the term of this Agreement will be automatically extended until December 31, 1999.
perturbation.changed_text: Unless either party gives the other at least thirty days' prior written notice that it has elected not to extend the term of this Agreement beyond December 31, 1998, the term of this Agreement will be automatically extended until December 31, 1999.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for non-renewal from 90 days to 30 days could be problematic if state law mandates a longer notification period for contracts of this nature, especially concerning healthcare-related services. Some states might view this as an unreasonably short period to allow for alternative arrangements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of state laws requiring specific notice periods for contract non-renewal, particularly for healthcare contracts.

perturbation.original_text: In the event that either party materially or repeatedly defaults in the performance of any of its duties or obligations hereunder and does not substantially cure such default within thirty days after being given written notice specifying the default, or, with respect to those defaults which cannot reasonably be cured within thirty days, if the defaulting party fails to proceed promptly after being given such notice to commence curing the default and thereafter to reasonably proceed to cure the same, then the party not in default
perturbation.changed_text: In the event that either party materially or repeatedly defaults in the performance of any of its duties or obligations hereunder and does not substantially cure such default within ten days after being given written notice specifying the default, or, with respect to those defaults which cannot reasonably be cured within ten days, if the defaulting party fails to proceed promptly after being given such notice to commence curing the default and thereafter to reasonably proceed to cure the same, then the party not in default
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for defaults from thirty days to ten days may be considered unreasonable in some jurisdictions, especially for complex contractual obligations in healthcare. This shortened timeframe could potentially violate fairness principles and legal standards requiring reasonable opportunity to cure breaches, potentially making the termination clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of legal principles requiring a reasonable cure period for contractual defaults, potentially conflicting with common law contract doctrines of fairness and good faith.
